title: Calculating Risk
text: expected risk policy alternative can estimated using outputs multiple model runs different input parameter sets, outlined box . Additionally, weighted version formula, accounts simulation runs different weights, provided. expected risk calculated pre-defined time range (\(t = t_{\rm min}…t_{\rm max}\)), selected capture important features decision problem, maximum duration policy options considered might adopted. decision threshold (\(D_{\rm t}\)) can either maximum, maximum hospital capacity, minimum, target number vaccinations delivered. decision threshold (\(D_{\rm t}\)) can also different values different time periods , example, hospital capacity expected change time. ensure consistent basis comparison, important decision threshold (\(D_{\rm t}\)) values, total number simulations (\(N\)), time range (\(t = t_{\rm min}…t_{\rm max}\)) consistent across baseline scenario policy alternatives compared.

title: Calculating Risk
text: \[ {\small \textrm{Expected Risk} =   \begin{cases}   \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n = 1}^{N}  \sum_{t = t_{\rm min}}^{t_{\rm max}}(\max(D_t, O_{nt})-D_t) &\textrm{} D_t \textrm{ maximum} \\   \\\   \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n = 1}^{N}  \sum_{t = t_{\rm min}}^{t_{\rm max}}(D_t - \min(D_t, O_{nt})) &\textrm{} D_t \textrm{ minimum}   \end{cases} } \] \(n = 1…N\) number simulations runs analysis, \(t = t_{\rm min}…t_{\rm max}\) simulation time expected risk calculated, \(O_{\rm nt}\) model outcome result simulation run \(n\) time \(t\), \(D_{\rm t}\) decision threshold given time (stated policy objective), can maximum minimum. Expected Risk value calculation implies following assumptions: () distribution neutrality deviations Dt: certain risk exceeding Dt 10 value risk distributed equally exceedance either 0 20; (ii) linearity cumulative risk: exceedance 1 100 days value exceedance 10 10 days.

title: Calculating Risk
text: \[ {\small \textrm{Expected Risk} =   \begin{cases}   \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n = 1}^{N} W_n \times \sum_{t = t_{\rm min}}^{t_{\rm max}}(\max(D_t, O_{nt})-D_t) &\textrm{} D_t \textrm{ maximum} \\   \\\   \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n = 1}^{N} W_n \times \sum_{t = t_{\rm min}}^{t_{\rm max}}(D_t - \min(D_t, O_{nt})) &\textrm{} D_t \textrm{ minimum}   \end{cases} } \] \(n = 1…N\) number simulations runs analysis, \(t = t_{\rm min}…t_{\rm max}\) simulation time, \(O_{\rm nt}\) model outcome result simulation run \(n\) time \(t\), \(D_{\rm t}\) decision threshold given time (stated policy objective), \(W_{\rm n}\) weight value simulation run \(n\).

title: Calculating Risk
text: First, calculate expected risk policy alternative using calculate_risk() function. policy objective ensure hospital demand remains available daily hospital capacity 750 patients, defines decision threshold. consider baseline scenario represented expected outcome absence intervention (.e., taking action) hypothetical policy alternative (Intervention 1 – close schools). considered time range 100 days starting 2021-01-01, corresponding first day policy implementation. use model outputs 814 simulation runs incorporate parameter uncertainty baseline scenario Intervention 1. expected risk values policy alternative challenging interpret independently. intuitive understanding can achieved using pre-defined baseline scenario comparator calculating percent change risk relative baseline scenario. defined policy risk impact, can calculated policy alternative using tabulate_risk() function.
code: # define inputs tmin <- min(psa_data$Intervention_1[, 1]) # minimum simulation time tmax <- max(psa_data$Intervention_1[, 1]) # maximum simulation time Dt <- c(rep(750, length(tmin:tmax))) # decision threshold vector Dt_max <- TRUE # indicates the threshold values are maximums  # calculate risk measure risk_measures_list <- calculate_risk(psa_data, tmin, tmax, Dt, Dt_max)  risk_measures_list #> $Baseline #> [1] 23078.21 #>  #> $Intervention_1 #> [1] 2007.469 ## generate risk table risk_table <- tabulate_risk(risk_measures_list,   n_s = length(risk_measures_list) )  risk_table #>                    Baseline   Intervention 1 #> Risk               "23078.21" "2007.47"      #> Policy risk impact "-"        "-91.30%"

title: Calculating Risk
text: cases, risk table presented alone accompanied plots described vignettes provide additional context. also recommend following standard description presenting risk table decision-makers. provide standard description paragraph bullet point form ease use.

title: Calculating Risk
text: expected risk values first row table capture probability scenario exceeding1 specified policy target (.e., likely ), magnitude exceedance2 target, length time exceedance3 likely last. Higher risk values indicate greater risk scenario achieve policy objective. Interpretation risk value intuitive using relative comparator. policy risk impact second row table compares risk associated intervention baseline scenario. policy risk impact interpreted percent change risk relative baseline scenario. example, expected risk exceeding4 policy target Intervention 1 reduced 91.30% relative baseline scenario.

previous_headings: Calculating risk with DUToolkit > Sharing outputs
title: Calculating Risk
text: expected risk values first row table captures: probability scenario exceeding5 specified policy target (.e., likely ). magnitude exceedance6 target. length time exceedance7 likely last. Higher risk values indicate greater risk scenario achieve policy objective. policy risk impact second row table: Compares risk associated intervention baseline scenario. interpreted percent change risk relative baseline scenario. example, expected risk exceeding8 policy target Intervention 1 reduced 91.5% relative baseline scenario.

title: Probability density plots with risk shading
text: proability density plots supplement risk table time-outcome fan plots quantifying visually displaying likely outcome projected peak exceed threshold, capturing downside risk associated projected peak outcome. also recommend following standard description presenting probability density plots decision-makers. provide standard description paragraph bullet point form ease use.

title: Probability density plots with risk shading
text: probability density graphs show distribution highest1 forecasted outcome2 (.e., peak3). red dashed line indicates policy target. shaded area indicates likely outcome4 forecasted peak5 exceed6 policy target, simply, amount downside risk. larger shaded area means downside risk.

title: Probability density plots with risk shading
text: probability density graphs show: distribution highest7 forecasted outcome8 (.e., peak9). red dashed line indicates policy target. shaded area indicates likely outcome10 forecasted peak11 exceed12 policy target (.e, amount downside risk). larger shaded area means downside risk.

title: Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit functions fall five main categories: Calculating risk: includes calculate_risk() tabulate_risk() Time-outcome fan plot: includes plot_fan() calculate_time() Probability density plots risk shading: includes get_max_min_values(), plot_density(), calculate_threshold_probs(), calculate_max_min_risk() Raincloud plots: includes plot_raincloud() Temporal probability density plots: includes get_relative_values(), plot_temporal(), sum_stats_temporal()

title: Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit package includes pre-loaded synthetic model outputs stored R object psa_data, serve example dataset. dataset represents hypothetical scenario decision-maker selecting two policies related COVID-19 2020: () Baseline – nothing/current state (ii) Intervention 1 – close schools. policy expected impact number individuals hospital. Hospital capacity maximum upper bound, decision threshold.

title: Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit functions require model outputs multiple simulation runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity analysis, general uncertainty analysis, Bayesian inference). outputs must follow standardized format, follows: list must contain one data.frame policy alternative. data.frame must : first column representing model time, either numeric values, (e.g., 1, 2, 3, …) dates R Date format (e.g., 2021-01-01, 2021-01-02, …) class = “Date”. Subsequent columns containing predicted outputs simulation run corresponding time points (e.g., 100 simulations, 101 columns data.frame). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column identical across policy alternatives (.e., first column every data.frame contain values). list vectors containing weights (Optional) simulation runs may less likely others. Various methods can account , calculating log-likelihood simulation run converting weight. Users must choose appropriate method specific scenario. vector list corresponds specific policy alternative contains weights assigned simulation run. weight vector must : number elements number simulation run columns corresponding output data.frame (.e., columns except first column). order weights must match order simulation run columns corresponding data.frame.

title: Time-outcome fan plots
text: plots visually illustrate uncertainty outcome (case, hospital demand) policy facilitate assessment relation decision threshold (hospital capacity). can used visually assess probability exceeding threshold understand expected magnitude, timing, duration exceedances. plots presented alongside risk measures provide decision-makers quantitative measure risk associated policy, alongside visual representation uncertainty additional context. also recommend following standard description presenting time-outcome fan plots decision-makers. provide standard description paragraph bullet point form ease use.

title: Time-outcome fan plots
text: graphs visually displays uncertainty surrounding scenario’s probability exceeding1 specified policy target. indicate degree uncertainty also provides insight magnitude intervention likely exceed2 target (percentile shading) anticipated duration exceedance3. magnitude length time shaded areas extends beyond4 policy target (dashed red line) signifies risk scenario achieve policy objective. shaded area above5 dashed red line longer periods indicates higher risk achieving policy objective.

title: Time-outcome fan plots
text: graphs visually display: uncertainty surrounding scenario’s probability exceeding6 specified policy target. also provides insight magnitude intervention likely exceed7 target (percentile shading) anticipated duration exceedance8. magnitude length time shaded areas extends beyond9 policy target (dashed red line) signifies risk scenario achieve policy objective. shaded area above10 dashed red line longer periods indicates higher risk achieving policy objective.

title: 01. Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit functions fall five main categories: Calculating risk: includes calculate_risk() tabulate_risk() Time-outcome fan plot: includes plot_fan() calculate_time() Probability density plots risk shading: includes get_max_min_values(), plot_density(), calculate_threshold_probs(), calculate_max_min_risk() Raincloud plots: includes plot_raincloud() Temporal probability density plots: includes get_relative_values(), plot_temporal(), sum_stats_temporal()

title: 01. Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit package includes pre-loaded synthetic model outputs stored R object psa_data, serve example dataset. dataset represents hypothetical scenario decision-maker selecting two policies related COVID-19 2020: () Baseline – nothing/current state (ii) Intervention 1 – close schools. policy expected impact number individuals hospital. Hospital capacity maximum upper bound, decision threshold.

title: 01. Introduction to DUToolkit
text: DUToolkit functions require model outputs multiple simulation runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity analysis, general uncertainty analysis, Bayesian inference). outputs must follow standardized format, follows: list must contain one data.frame policy alternative. data.frame must : first column representing model time, either numeric values, (e.g., 1, 2, 3, …) dates R Date format (e.g., 2021-01-01, 2021-01-02, …) class = “Date”. Subsequent columns containing predicted outputs simulation run corresponding time points. ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column identical across policy alternatives (.e., first column every data.frame contain values). list vectors containing weights (Optional) simulation runs may less likely others. Various methods can account , calculating log-likelihood simulation run converting weight. Users must choose appropriate method specific scenario. vector list corresponds specific policy alternative contains weights assigned simulation run. weight vector must : number elements number simulation run columns corresponding output data.frame (.e., columns except first column). order weights must match order simulation run columns corresponding data.frame.

title: Raincloud plots
text: raincloud plot can supplement probability density plots providing intuitive direct visual comparison severity situation expected peak policy alternative single plot. also recommend following standard description presenting raincloud plots decision-makers. provide standard description paragraph bullet point form ease use.

title: Raincloud plots
text: graph shows distribution highest1 forecasted outcome2 (.e., peak3) scenario alongside corresponding box plot indicates mean 50th percentile range. interventions displayed single graph allow visual comparison. red dashed line indicates policy target. distribution area located right4 policy target line, greater probability outcome5 forecasted peak6 surpass7 policy target.

title: Raincloud plots
text: graph shows: distribution highest8 forecasted outcome9 (.e., peak10) scenario single graph allow visual comparison. corresponding box plot scenario indicates mean 50th percentile range. red dashed line indicates policy target. distribution area located right11 policy target line, greater probability outcome12 forecasted peak13 surpass14 policy target.

title: Temporal probability density plots
text: probability density plotted center peak temporal plot (labelled ‘peak’) probability density plotted plot_density() function plot_raincloud() function. temporal probability density plots can supplement probability density plots showing uncertainty changes time scenario. also recommend following standard description presenting temporal probability density plots decision-makers. provide standard description paragraph bullet point form ease use.

title: Temporal probability density plots
text: graph visually illustrates uncertainty changes time showing distributions forecasted outcome1 time. distribution center plot represents peak2 outcome3. distributions show outcome different time points relative peak4, forward () backward () time. red dashed line indicates policy target. greater area right5 line means higher risk outcome6 exceeding7 policy target specified time. Scenarios area right8 policy target quickly reduced move away peak9 result shorter periods time higher risk achieving policy target.

title: Temporal probability density plots
text: graphs visually illustrates uncertainty changes time: distribution center plot represents peak10 outcome11. distributions show outcome different time points relative peak12, forward () backward () time. red dashed line indicates policy target. greater area right13 line means higher chance outcome14 exceeding15 policy target specified time. Scenarios area right16 policy target quickly reduced move away peak17 result shorter time frame higher uncertainty.

what: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
title: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
text: policy alternative, function calculates risk measure peak values (lowest values threshold minimum).

title: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
code: calculate_max_min_risk(max_min_values_list, D, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
text: max_min_values_list list generated get_max_min_values() D single threshold value Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
text: list risk measure values.

title: Calculate risk measures at peak (or minimum) — calculate_max_min_risk
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" D <- 750  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  calculate_max_min_risk(   peak_values_list,   D = D,   Dt_max = TRUE ) #> $Baseline #> [1] 1500.787 #>  #> $Intervention_1 #> [1] 156.5167 #>

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
text: function calculates expected risk measure policy alternative using outputs multiple model runs different input parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis).

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
code: calculate_risk(data, tmin, tmax, Dt, Dt_max = TRUE, W = FALSE, weight = NULL)

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
text: data list data.frames (one data.frame policy alternative). tmin numeric value date specifying minimum simulation time include analysis (ex. 1 "2021-01-01"). correspond value first column data.frame data. tmax numeric value date specifying maximum simulation time include analysis (ex. 100 "2021-04-10"). correspond value first column data.frame data. Dt numeric vector decision thresholds, one model time step tmin tmax. Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE. W logical value indicating whether risk calculation weighted (TRUE) (FALSE). default FALSE (equal weight 1 assumed simulation runs). weight list numeric vectors weights risk calculation, one weight corresponding time step. Required W TRUE.

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
text: list risk scores, one policy alternative.

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
text: data.frame data contains results multiple model runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis). first column contains model time subsequent columns contain predicted output simulation run respective time. model time first column must contain numeric values indicating simulation time (ex. 1, 2, 3,...) dates (ex. "2021-01-01", "2021-01-02") must R Date format (.e., class="Date"). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column policy alternative (data.frame).

title: Calculate risk measures — calculate_risk
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline))  calculate_risk(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt = Dt,   Dt_max = TRUE ) #> $Baseline #> [1] 23078.21 #>  #> $Intervention_1 #> [1] 2007.469 #>

title: Calculate threshold exceedance probabilities — calculate_threshold_probs
text: policy alternative, function calculates probability peak (minimum) value exceeds () specified threshold(s) using Riemann sum approach.

title: Calculate threshold exceedance probabilities — calculate_threshold_probs
code: calculate_threshold_probs(max_min_values_list, Dp, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Calculate threshold exceedance probabilities — calculate_threshold_probs
text: max_min_values_list list generated get_max_min_values() Dp vector threshold values calculate probabilities . Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Calculate threshold exceedance probabilities — calculate_threshold_probs
text: list vectors threshold values corresponding probabilities.

title: Calculate threshold exceedance probabilities — calculate_threshold_probs
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" D <- 750 Dp <- c(750, 1000, 2000)  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  calculate_threshold_probs(   peak_values_list,   Dp = Dp,   Dt_max = TRUE ) #> $Baseline #>    750   1000   2000  #> 0.9494 0.8887 0.5895  #>  #> $Intervention_1 #>    750   1000   2000  #> 0.4876 0.2537 0.0013  #>

what: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
text: policy alternative, function calculates: () percent simulations threshold exceeded (met threshold minimum), (ii) mean simulation time first exceedance 95th percentile range, (iii) mean duration first exceedance 95th percentile range, (iv) first column model output data.frame passed function Date, mean date first last exceedance.

title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
code: calculate_time(data, tmin, tmax, Dt, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
text: data list data.frames (one data.frame policy alternative). tmin numeric value date specifying minimum simulation time include analysis (ex. 1 "2021-01-01"). correspond value first column data.frame data. tmax numeric value date specifying maximum simulation time include analysis (ex. 100 "2021-04-10"). correspond value first column data.frame data. Dt numeric vector decision thresholds, one model time step tmin tmax. Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
text: list data.frames, one policy alternative.

title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
text: data.frame data contains results multiple model runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis). first column contains model time subsequent columns contain predicted output simulation run respective time. model time first column must contain numeric values indicating simulation time (ex. 1, 2, 3,...) dates (ex. "2021-01-01", "2021-01-02") must R Date format (.e., class="Date"). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column policy alternative (data.frame).

title: Calculate time of threshold exceedance — calculate_time
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline))  calculate_time(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt = Dt,   Dt_max = TRUE ) #> $Baseline #>     percent_sims time_first 2.5% 97.5% duration_first 2.5% 97.5% date_first #> out    0.9532595   22.88516   16    35       25.03484    9    34 2021-01-23 #>      date_last #> out 2021-02-17 #>  #> $Intervention_1 #>     percent_sims time_first 2.5% 97.5% duration_first 2.5% 97.5% date_first #> out    0.4846248   23.97462   18    33        16.3731    3    28 2021-01-24 #>      date_last #> out 2021-02-09 #>

what: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
text: policy alternative, function finds peak (lowest threshold minimum) model output values simulation run.

title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
code: get_max_min_values(data, tmin, tmax, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
text: data list data.frames (one data.frame policy alternative). tmin numeric value date specifying minimum simulation time include analysis (ex. 1 "2021-01-01"). correspond value first column data.frame data. tmax numeric value date specifying maximum simulation time include analysis (ex. 100 "2021-04-10"). correspond value first column data.frame data. Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
text: list data.frame(s) containing peak (lowest) value corresponding simulation time policy alternative.

title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
text: data.frame data contains results multiple model runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis). first column contains model time subsequent columns contain predicted output simulation run respective time. model time first column must contain numeric values indicating simulation time (ex. 1, 2, 3,...) dates (ex. "2021-01-01", "2021-01-02") must R Date format (.e., class="Date"). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column policy alternative (data.frame).

title: Finds peak (or lowest) model output values — get_max_min_values
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline))  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )

what: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
text: policy alternative, function finds model output values simulation run specified time points relative peak (minimum) value.

title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
code: get_relative_values(data, max_min_values_list, t_s, t_ss, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
text: data list data.frames (one data.frame policy alternative). max_min_values_list list generated get_max_min_values(). t_s total time window examine peak (minimum) value. t_ss interval size sampling time points within specified time window t_s. example, t_s = 20 t_ss = 10 function extract values peak_time-20, peak_time-10, peak_time, peak_time+10, peak_time+20. Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
text: list nested lists following elements: () data.frame values recorded specific time steps relative peak time (e.g., peak-10, peak, peak+10) model run, (ii) vector names time step ex. minus_30,minus_20,...,plus_20, plus_30.

title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
text: data.frame data contains results multiple model runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis). first column contains model time subsequent columns contain predicted output simulation run respective time. model time first column must contain numeric values indicating simulation time (ex. 1, 2, 3,...) dates (ex. "2021-01-01", "2021-01-02") must R Date format (.e., class="Date"). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column policy alternative (data.frame).

title: Find output values at time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — get_relative_values
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" D <- 750 t_s <- 20 t_ss <- 10  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  peak_temporal_list <- get_relative_values(   psa_data,   peak_values_list,   t_s = t_s,   t_ss = t_ss )

title: Generate density plots — plot_density
text: policy alternative, function generates probability density plots highest (lowest threshold minimum) projected outcome across simulation runs. decision threshold shown directly plot vertical line. area probability density curve threshold value exceeded shaded visually display downside risk policy alternative.

title: Generate density plots — plot_density
code: plot_density(max_min_values_list, D, Dt_max = TRUE, risk_measures)

title: Generate density plots — plot_density
text: max_min_values_list list generated get_max_min_values() D single threshold value Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE. risk_measures list risk scores generated calculate_risk(). policy alternatives risk_measures list must order max_min_values_list.

title: Generate density plots — plot_density
text: list ggplots, one policy alternative.

title: Generate density plots — plot_density
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline)) D <- 750  risk_measures <- calculate_risk(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt = Dt,   Dt_max = TRUE )  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  density_plots <- plot_density(   peak_values_list,   D = D,   Dt_max = TRUE,   risk_measures )

title: Generate time-outcome fan plots — plot_fan
text: policy alternative, function generates time-outcome fan plots summarizing trajectory outcome time using mean value given policy alternative. Uncertainty characterized shading 50% 95% credible intervals (calculated 25th 75th percentiles 2.5th 97.5th percentiles, respectively). decision threshold shown directly plot provide clear reference point interpreting outcome values.

title: Generate time-outcome fan plots — plot_fan
code: plot_fan(data, tmin, tmax, Dt, Dt_max = TRUE)

title: Generate time-outcome fan plots — plot_fan
text: data list data.frames (one data.frame policy alternative). tmin numeric value date specifying minimum simulation time include analysis (ex. 1 "2021-01-01"). correspond value first column data.frame data. tmax numeric value date specifying maximum simulation time include analysis (ex. 100 "2021-04-10"). correspond value first column data.frame data. Dt numeric vector decision thresholds, one model time step tmin tmax. Dt_max logical value indicating whether decision threshold maximum (TRUE) minimum (FALSE). default TRUE.

title: Generate time-outcome fan plots — plot_fan
text: list ggplots, one policy alternative.

title: Generate time-outcome fan plots — plot_fan
text: data.frame data contains results multiple model runs using different parameter sets (e.g., probabilistic sensitivity, uncertainty, Bayesian inference analysis). first column contains model time subsequent columns contain predicted output simulation run respective time. model time first column must contain numeric values indicating simulation time (ex. 1, 2, 3,...) dates (ex. "2021-01-01", "2021-01-02") must R Date format (.e., class="Date"). ensure consistent basis comparison, model time first column policy alternative (data.frame).

code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline))  fan_plots <- plot_fan(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt = Dt,   Dt_max = TRUE )

title: Generate temporal probability density plots — plot_temporal
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" D <- 750 t_s <- 30 t_ss <- 10  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  peak_temporal_list <- get_relative_values(   psa_data,   peak_values_list,   t_s = t_s,   t_ss = t_ss )  peak_temporal_plots <- plot_temporal(   peak_temporal_list,   D )

title: Sample PSA data — psa_data

title: Sample PSA data — psa_data
code: psa_data

title: Sample PSA data — psa_data

what: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
title: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
text: policy alternative, function calculates summary statistics (n, mean, median, IQR) model output values specified time points relative peak (minimum) value.

title: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
code: sum_stats_temporal(relative_values)

title: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
text: relative_values list generated get_relative_values().

title: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
text: list data.frames summary statistics.

title: Calculates summary statistics at specified time points relative to the peak (or minimum) — sum_stats_temporal
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" D <- 750 t_s <- 20 t_ss <- 10  peak_values_list <- get_max_min_values(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt_max = TRUE )  peak_temporal_list <- get_relative_values(   psa_data,   peak_values_list,   t_s = t_s,   t_ss = t_ss )  stats_peak_temporal <- sum_stats_temporal(peak_temporal_list)

what: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
title: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
text: function tabulates expected risk values policy alternative percent change risk relative baseline scenario.

title: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
code: tabulate_risk(exp_risk_list, n_s)

title: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
text: exp_risk_list list expected risk values first element corresponds baseline policy. list can generated using calculate_risk() function. n_s numeric value number policy alternatives (including baseline policy) include table.

title: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
text: character matrix risk values policy risk impact (%) policy alternative.

title: Output risk measures to table — tabulate_risk
code: tmin <- "2021-01-01" tmax <- "2021-04-10" Dt <- rep(750, nrow(psa_data$Baseline))  risk_measures <- calculate_risk(   psa_data,   tmin = tmin,   tmax = tmax,   Dt = Dt,   Dt_max = TRUE )  tabulate_risk(   risk_measures,   n_s = length(psa_data) ) #>                    Baseline   Intervention 1 #> Risk               "23078.21" "2007.47"      #> Policy risk impact "-"        "-91.30%"
